It is said that the dependent origination of the name and so forth refers to the dependent origination of the name based on the previous cause and condition.
Dependent origination. It is said that one gives rise to superior understanding.

It means that there is no dharma of transmission and reception between the two dharmas of ignorance and karmic activity, so it is called emptiness. It is said that the details are explained as before.
Explaining the two worldly faults of dispute and harm, etc.
As explained before in the contemplation of impurity. All actions
Refers to the three kinds of actions, good, etc. The fruit of a single entity
Refers to the universal inclusion of sentient and non-sentient dependent origination. The fruit of experiencing objects
Refers to only discussing sentient beings. In this world, etc.
Refers to the body born as the fruit of the five destinies in the present world. The six sense bases
Refers to the six sense organs. Causing the arising of sprouts
Refers to the arising of the sprouts of the three kinds of actions, etc., due to ignorance as the cause.
Refuting the mutual dependence, etc. All grasping
Refers to grasping at self-existence, grasping at desire, grasping at precepts and observances, etc. Having internal realization
Refers to the practitioners in the five stages who directly see the two dharmas of ignorance, etc., in forward and reverse order.
Because they are able to practice and realize the superior fruits. Inferring the dharmas
It means that by contemplating the forward and reverse progressions of dependent origination, one attains the holy fruits.
I also contemplate this and realize the higher fruits. As for able to correctly understand,
it means that because the six elements such as earth have different natures, one can investigate them. As for the meaning of seeds,
it means that because the six dharmas such as earth are the seeds, there are bodies in the five destinies. As for the meaning of causes,
it means that because the six dharmas such as earth are the causes, bodies in the five destinies are born. As for the meaning of natures,
it means that each of the dharmas such as earth has the natures of solidity, etc. As for the meaning of being the elements,
it is for the sake of the above four meanings. As for the single combined appearance,
it means that because one does not understand that there are six elements in the body,
one only gives rise to the view of a single self, which is called the single combined appearance. As for having correct investigation, etc.,
it means that non-Buddhists consider the self to be the cause, and therefore enter the mother's womb.
This is not so in this case.
Because of the six elements, one enters the mother's womb. As for abiding in the nature of dharmas,
it means that the six elements such as earth, water, etc., whether Buddhas appear in the world or not, are equal and thus called abiding. As for long exhalation,
it means ten breaths as one count, etc. As for completely without holding exhalation, etc.,
it means that within the various activities such as the aggregates, etc., there is completely no support for the two views of self and person, etc. As for causes,
it refers to karma and afflictions. As for conditions,
it refers to the parents' semen and blood, etc. As for various activities,
it refers to the characteristics of the fruits. As for skillful means, etc.,
there is a question here.
Among the four conditions, the six meanings of the objects of practice as explained above have
already been understood.
The third skillful means object
and the fourth object of purifying delusions,
why are the six distinctions not explained?
Therefore, the treatise answers, If one relies on skillful means, etc. The phrase in this regard
refers to the four kinds of wisdom that observe the three gates and six matters, and the five kinds of contemplation that destroy impurity.
This is because the nine kinds of preparatory practices accomplish the contemplation gate.
Therefore, the treatise states, nine kinds, etc. The phrase attaining concentration

means that practitioners in the five stages quickly attain the fundamental concentrations of the five stages due to the nine kinds of preparatory practices. The phrase in the stage to which one should go, etc.
means that practitioners in the five stages, due to cultivating the nine kinds of preparatory practices,
quickly attain the stage of added effort, etc., in the stage of equipment. The phrase equal division
means that the afflictions of the five stages are not biased towards one, and are therefore called equal division. The phrase thin defilements
means that practitioners in the five stages are in the upper stages. The phrase according to one's preference, etc.

means that the two types of practitioners, those of equal practice and those of equal person, cultivate the methods of antidotes in order to first arouse whichever afflictions arise among the five stages.

It means that among the six recollections, etc., taking any one of them is called lifting up. As for it is said that, etc.,
It means that when the mind is sunken,

It means that among the five contemplations such as impurity, etc., one who diligently makes effort is the characteristic of lifting up. As for the object, etc.,
It means that in the mind that is not defiled by objects that accord with or go against one's feelings, the mind is equal.
In tranquility and insight, it also turns equally. As for it is said that, etc.,
That is, when the mind does not dwell in the agreeable, disagreeable, cessation, or contemplation, it is called the mark of equanimity. As for the superior equanimity,
it means to take the equanimity of the higher and higher stages. As for the phrase in regard to such things,
it means in regard to the objects of the two dharmas of cessation and contemplation.
As explained above, one attains skill in each of them. As for the phrase well grasping, etc.,
it refers to the three minds of beginning, middle, and end. As for the phrase sometimes abandoning,

it means not violating the precepts and training one has received, which is called not abandoning the yoke.
It means that one who cultivates the eight dharmas such as being without holes is called one who does not transgress. As for what is said about what was done a long time ago, etc.,
It means that regarding one's own bodily actions and the three actions of speech and mind,
One should not follow and create unwholesome [actions].
One should follow and create the ten wholesome actions.
Therefore, the treatise text says, One is able to recall the causes, etc. As for frequently giving rise to superior understanding,
It refers to the path of the remedy. As for frequently correctly eliminating,
It refers to the dharmas that are to be eliminated.

One is the meaning of superior understanding,

Since these two are both correct practices, they are labeled with these two names. As for following the characteristics and practicing, etc.,

It means that within the twenty virtuous and wholesome concentrations, following and practicing any one of them is fully endowed with the superior understanding that is the remedy and the elimination that is what is to be eliminated.
Here, a beginner should also be like this.

It is like a person who has long cultivated meditative practices and fully cultivates the above two practices, who is then called a person of correct practice. As for one should know this and so forth,
each of these five gates is endowed with both cause and effect.
The expounder should know. As for due to the initial and so forth,

it means that one who cultivates the contemplation of impurity and so forth must turn away from the characteristics of stillness and so forth that are inverted. As for due to taking other concentrations as objects and so forth,
it means that if the power of the concentration that one cultivates is weak and one is unable to eliminate the objects of elimination,
one should cultivate other concentrations to assist and accompany them, in order to establish the fundamental concentration. As for due to all and so forth,
it means that if one gives rise to defilements in regard to the various pure characteristics and so forth,
one should cultivate the contemplation of impurity and so forth to eliminate the various characteristics of purity and so forth. As for although universally established and so forth,
there is a question here.

that practitioners have different faculties and different afflictions.
When first cultivating, if greed is predominant, one should bind the mind to the contemplation of impurity.
If anger is predominant, one should bind the mind to the contemplation of kindness and compassion.
The rest are all the same as this.
Therefore, the treatise says or else, the place is the same, etc. The phrase only thinking like this, etc. means
that in the characteristics of the contemplation of impurity, etc., if there are characteristics such as purity, it is called distraction.
If there are characteristics such as impurity, it is called non-distraction.
The beginner should think like this.ğŸ”½How can my mind be without distraction?

The following nine types are each combined with the thought of only this and explained. As for without tranquility,
it means cutting off the current activity. As for intense tranquility,
it means cutting off the seeds and current activity. As for diligent in this way,
it is combined with each of the above ten texts. As for precisely by this,
it means that because of the cause of inwardly collecting the mind,
the practitioners in the five stages do not think of purity and so forth in the objects of meditation such as impurity and so forth. As for with characteristics,
it means the characteristics of impurity and so forth. As for with discrimination,
it means the discriminated images of impurity and so forth. As for it is said that by following the characteristics and so forth,
it means because of practicing the three kinds of wisdom such as investigation and so forth. As for their objects,
it means relying on the three kinds of wisdom to observe the faults and virtues of the five meditations such as impurity and so forth,
and not just practicing the single meditation on impurity.
As for the phrase still abandoning and so on,
there is a question here.
When cultivating the five contemplations, are only the three wisdoms used as skillful means?
Or must other dharmas be used as skillful means?
Therefore, the treatise answers with still and so on. As for the phrase due to the object and so on,
it means that if one abandons stillness, one will certainly become scattered, so it is called abandoning.
Because the nine kinds of abiding in the mind are included in the category of stillness, it is called not abandoning. As for the phrase just in regard to the object and so on,
it means that due to the contemplation of the six distinctions such as meaning,
in regard to what is to be abandoned, one does not create its characteristics, does not create the self, and does not give rise to the mind of distinction between self and what belongs to the self.
Therefore, it is called not grasping. As for the phrase there is in the middle and so on,
it means that due to the nine kinds of abiding in the mind as the cause,
one is able to abide in the contemplation of impurity and so on. As for the phrase grasping stillness and practice and so on,
it means that due to the investigation of the six distinctions such as meaning, impurity and so on,
It can serve as a skillful means for the practice of cessation.
Therefore, it is called the practice of cessation that takes the characteristics of the knowable as its object.ğŸ”½As for if one is able to...
It means that resolve is contemplation,ğŸ”½and dispelling is cessation.ğŸ”½As for due to repeated resolve...
As for in a narrow object...
It means that when cultivating the five contemplations such as impurity, etc.,
One first contemplates a finger joint, which is called narrow.
This gradually increases and is called vast.
Later, one contemplates the immeasurable in the ten directions.ğŸ”½Therefore, the treatise says vast, etc.
As for if all dharmas...
It means such as blue and festering.ğŸ”½The twenty virtuous concentrations all have form as their images.
As for all formless dharmas...

It means that the images of the four contemplations such as loving-kindness, compassion, etc., are only mental factors that transform and appear, and are therefore called not form.ğŸ”½As for liberation,
It means the fruit of nirvana.ğŸ”½As for separation,ğŸ”½It means the cause of nirvana.
As for defiled longing,
It refers to the mind that is not inclined to leave the five desires and so forth.
As for not delighting and so forth, it refers to the mind that does not delight in the cause and effect dharmas of nirvana, and gives rise to sorrow and distress.

As for inferior wisdom and views, it refers to giving rise to arrogance when realizing a small portion in the uninterrupted and liberated paths.ğŸ”½Therefore, the treatise says, It is as if I can attain...
As for and so forth as explained above, it refers to only I can attain... and so forth.
